channel.title: (Non-)Functional Ramblings
channel.description: A blog maintained by some guy that likes functional programming.

item.title: Can I pet your DAG?
item.description: Haskell's ordered maps are fun tools to have in any arsenal. In this post I give an example on doing dependency resolution quickly using the partially ordered nature of dependency relations, using an extremely contrived example.
item.dc:creator: Curtis Chin Jen Sem

item.title: Functional programmers enter a diner…
item.description: This post explores preventing concurrency deadlocks in Haskell by enforcing a fixed, predefined order for acquiring MVar locks. It details an interface that ensures safe, multi-threaded access to shared state components.
item.dc:creator: Curtis Chin Jen Sem

item.title: We’re All CHAMPs On The Inside
item.description: HAMT's are cool, Haskell has a ubiquitous one in unordered-containers. But other languages have the even cooler CHAMPs. This post is about optimizing the filter-ish functions in an attempt at a drop-in replacement that uses CHAMPs.
item.dc:creator: Curtis Chin Jen Sem

item.title: Harder-Coded Newtypes
item.description: Newtypes are generally useful to avoid parameter-blindness, but can be cumbersome if each type has it's own wrapper. I explore the use of TypeData and phantom types in Haskell as an alternative way to improve type safety and reduce developer errors.
item.dc:creator: Curtis Chin Jen Sem

item.title: Lazy-ing in My Pool
item.description: This blog post discusses the implementation of a lazy initialization strategy for managing a pool of resources. Emphasizing the importance of deferring initialization to improve performance in scenarios where not all resources are needed simultaneously.
item.dc:creator: Curtis Chin Jen Sem

item.title: Better than Revivify
item.description: This blog post discusses my journey of revitalizing my long-neglected website, transitioning to using Hakyll. Including styling with Clay, implementing syntax highlighting with Pygments, using KaTeX for mathematical typesetting, and optimizing font usage.
item.dc:creator: Curtis Chin Jen Sem

item.title: What’s in the Name?
item.description: This blog post explores different approaches to implementing a lambda calculus interpreter. It examines various representation methods, including first-order representations and higher-order abstract syntax (HOAS).
item.dc:creator: Curtis Chin Jen Sem

item.title: Roly, Oly, …, Polyvariadic Boogaloo
item.description: In the blog post, I author revisits the topic of polyvariadic functions in Haskell, building on a previous attempt by introducing type families to create a more streamlined implementation.
item.dc:creator: Curtis Chin Jen Sem

item.title: Roly, Oly, …, Polyvariadic
item.description: This blog post illustrates the concept of polyvariadic functions, using the example of a function that can sum an arbitrary number of integers or return another function.
item.dc:creator: Curtis Chin Jen Sem

item.title: Flooding my ’base
item.description: I discuss populating a database with generated data, resulting in a simple solution that generates objects sequentially, following a topological sort to ensure dependency preservation.
item.dc:creator: Curtis Chin Jen Sem
